author: Helen Yemm
title: An alternative to plastic pots
text: The fad for ornamental galvanised plant containers seems, if anything, to be gathering momentum. They look smart – smarter than a lot of plastic pots – with some made in svelte modern shapes beloved by minimalists. • How can I hide my hot tub? The best-quality ones last well, the initial garish brilliance dulling down nicely in time and acquiring, for those who go for such things, a fashionable “vintage” look. But practical they are not. The reason is fairly obvious, if you think about it. While they are not porous (and therefore don’t, like terracotta, dry out quickly), they heat up fast in the sun and give no protection when temperatures plummet. Plant roots do not thrive in such extremes. You can insulate them to a degree by lining the insides with bubble wrap, which is a bit of a fiddle. • How do I grow orlaya? Or buy them roomy enough to hide a smaller inner plastic pot. A final caveat: beware of those many that are sold with no drainage holes: no, it won’t do just to put a lot of crocks in the bottom and hope your plants won’t drown, boil or roast. They will do all three. • How do I get rid of black beetles on roses? telegraph.co.uk Follow @telegraph
